metadata.title: Imidazole versus pyridine as ligands for metalloporphine immobilization in ligninolytic peroxidases-like biomimetic catalysts

Fig. 1 Synthesis of (3-[1-imidazolyl]-propylcarbamoyl)-3′-aminopropylsilica (IPS, a) and 4-pyridyl-methyl-carbamoyl-aminopropylsilica (PSG, b). Chemical structures of the catalysts described in the present study: IPS/MnTDCPP (c) and PSG/MnTDCPP (d). Fig. 2 FT-IR spectra of the described functionalized supports and catalysts. Fig. 3 Catalytic activity of IPS/MnTDCPP and PSG/MnTDCPP is dependent on pH. Data are reported using hydrogen peroxide as the oxidant, both in the absence and in the presence of Mn(II) as redox mediator, with VA (a), ARS (b), and AzB (c) as reducing substrates. % Catalytic activity is referred to maximum conversion rate obtained for each substrate. n =3. Fig. 4 Catalytic activity of IPS/MnTDCPP and PSG/MnTDCPP is dependent on pH. Data are reported using luperox as the oxidant, both in the absence and in the presence of Mn(II) as redox mediator, with VA (a), ARS (b), and AzB (c) as reducing substrates. % Catalytic activity is referred to maximum conversion rate obtained for each substrate. n =3. Fig. 5 IPS/MnTDCPP (a) and PSG/MnTDCPP (b) cause different UV/vis spectral modifications during oxidation of AzB. Fig. 6 IPS/MnTDCPP and PSG/MnTDCPP effectively bleach several dyes belonging to different chemical classes. The reactions were performed at pH 8. % Dye removal is the % of initial dyes removed in 1h from solution. n =3. Table 1 Functionalization and metalloporphine loading of IPS and PSG. Degree of functionalization is expressed as micromoles of imidazole/pyridine residues per gram of support. The loading of MnTDCPP is also reported as micromoles of metalloporphine per gram functionalized support. n =3. Catalytic assays were performed at pH 8, both in the presence of hydrogen peroxide and luperox as the oxidants. % Conversion is the % of initial substrate removed from solution in 1h. n =3. For each substrate, the optimum conditions of activity were chosen (compare Fig. 3), using hydrogen peroxide as the oxidant. % Conversion is the % of initial substrate removed from solution. n =3. Cycle number % VA conversion % ARS conversion % AzB conversion IPS/MnTDCPP PSG/MnTDCPP IPS/MnTDCPP PSG/MnTDCPP IPS/MnTDCPP PSG/MnTDCPP 1 100±1 100±1 100±1 100±1 100±1 100±1 2 93±4 66±5 94±3 73±1 100±5 64±5 3 97±2 58±3 89±2 72±4 101±3 57±4 4 93±2 54±1 88±5 73±3 100±2 59±2 5 89±3 52±4 86±3 72±4 89±2 57±2 6 83±4 47±2 88±2 73±3 92±4 58±3 7 60±4 37±4 88±4 72±2 95±3 60±2 8 55±3 30±5 90±4 67±4 72±2 59±2 9 52±1 31±3 87±2 66±3 73±1 38±4 10 50±3 28±2 84±1 65±4 66±2 35±3 Imidazole versus pyridine as ligands for metalloporphine immobilization in ligninolytic peroxidases-like biomimetic catalysts Paolo Zucca a b Gianmarco Cocco b Stefania Manca b Daniela Steri b Enrico Sanjust b ⁎ a Consorzio UNO (Consortium for University at Oristano), Oristano, Italy Consorzio UNO (Consortium for University at Oristano) Oristano Italy b Dipartimento di Scienze Biomediche, Università di Cagliari, Italy Dipartimento di Scienze Biomediche, Università di Cagliari Italy ⁎ Corresponding author at: Dipartimento di Scienze Biomediche, Università di Cagliari, Cittadella Universitaria, 09042 Monserrato (CA), Italy. Tel.: +39 070 675 4518; fax: +39 070 675 4527. Graphical abstract This paper describes the immobilization of 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(2,6-dichlorophenyl)porphine-manganese(III) through coordinative bond onto imidazolyl- and pyridyl-grafted silica, emulating the active site of ligninolytic peroxidases. To this purpose, plain silica gel was functionalized with two organosilanes: the first bearing an imidazolyl functionality, the other one bearing a pyridyl functionality. Manganese-porphine was then immobilized onto the two modified silicas. The two catalytic adducts have been fully characterized to point out the effect of the ligands on their catalytic features. Pyridine-immobilized metalloporphine was found to be a much more performant catalyst, giving significantly higher conversion rates with all the tested substrates: a lignin-model compound such as veratryl alcohol, the lignin peroxidase well-known substrate azure B, and recalcitrant textile dyes such as alizarin red S, phenosafranine, methylene blue, methyl green, xylenol orange, and methyl orange. Imidazole-immobilized metalloporphine on the contrary has proved to be more stable than its pyridine-based counterpart. Besides, the ligands seem to promote different catalytic pathways in the two adducts. These results allow giving rational and rigorous insights about the effect of the ligands during the immobilization of metalloporphines, thus helping in the design of catalysts with specific feature (i.e. stability, reactivity). Abbreviations SG silica gel IPS (3-[1-imidazolyl]-propylcarbamoyl)-3′-aminopropylsilica PSG 4-pyridyl-methyl-carbamoyl-aminopropylsilica MnTDCPP 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(2,6-dichlorophenyl)porphine-manganese(III) VA veratryl alcohol ARS alizarin red S AzB azure B PNS phenosafranine XO xylenol orange MG methyl green MB methylene blue MO methyl orange MnP manganese peroxidase, E.C. 1.11.1.13 LiP lignin peroxidase, E.C. 1.11.1.14 Keywords Metalloporphine Metalloporphyrin Biomimetic Lignin peroxidase Manganese peroxidase 1 Introduction Redox-active metalloporphines can use hydrogen peroxide or other suitable oxidants in several reactions, such as hydroxylation and epoxidation of hydrocarbons [1–3], as well as oxidation of phenols and aromatic alcohols [4–8], humic acids [9], sulfides [10], and textile dyes [11–13]. In particular, several electron-deficient metalloporphines have been synthetized (second and third generation metalloporphines [14]), showing promising catalytic features (chemical robustness, high conversion yields, stereo- and enantio-selectivity, possibility of mild operational conditions, etc.) [14,15]. Their ability to emulate several enzymes has been also described, with particular emphasis on cytochrome P-450 [16] and ligninolytic peroxidases [15]. The emulation of the latter class of enzymes suggests their use in the detoxification of recalcitrant aromatic phenolic and non-phenolic substrates, such as lignocellulosic wastes, olive-mill wastewaters, textile dyes [15] etc. In this applicative perspective, heterogenization of catalysts is compulsory for economic concerns. Several approaches have been attempted, including adsorption, encapsulation, ion exchange and covalent binding (recently reviewed in [15]). However, real biomimesis of ligninolytic peroxidases can be accomplished only through immobilization via coordinative bond involving the central metal ion. In fact, in enzyme active sites the imidazole of a histidine residue coordinates ferri-heme. Such an approach led not only to proper structural biomimesis, but also to increased stability and activity of the catalysts [4,14,17]. Imidazole can be also replaced by pyridine as metalloporphine ligand. Although pyridine is not biomimetic, pyridyl function as a ligand for redox-active metalloporphines is of potential interest for practical applications. In fact, the stronger electron-withdrawing effect of pyridine in comparison with imidazole alters the overall behavior of the obtained catalysts, acting in particular on the redox potentials of the resting metalloporphine and on the catalytic intermediates. Therefore, metalloporphines immobilized via coordinative bond to pyridyl functionality show promising catalytic features [10,18,19]. In this paper, we describe two novel catalysts based on a second generation metalloporphine, 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(2,6-dichlorophenyl)porphine-manganese(III) (MnTDCPP). This macrocycle has been immobilized via coordinative bond onto two modified silica supports functionalized with imidazole (IPS) and pyridine (PSG) moieties (Fig. 1c and d). And the effects of the two ligands on metalloporphine catalytic activity have been studied, giving also mechanistic insights. To this purpose, several oxidant and reducing substrates were included in the study, to evaluate catalytic activity under some operational conditions of potential applicative interest. The role of Mn2+ as a redox mediator was also studied to discern between LiP- and MnP-like activity. Recently, a comparative study about the effect of these ligands in homogenous phase has been carried out [20]. While, for what in our knowledge, the present study is the first report of a rigorous comparison about the effect of imidazole and pyridine – as ligands for metalloporphine immobilization – toward the catalytic behavior of the same immobilized metalloporphine. 2 Experimental All the reagents used were of the best grade available, and were used as purchased without further purification. Silica gel 100 (SG) came from Fluka (cat. no. 60746), 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(2,6-dichlorophenyl)porphine-manganese(III) (MnTDCPP) came from Porphyrin System (Lübeck, Germany, cat. no. PO890047), LiP (E.C. 1.11.1.14) was from Sigma–Aldrich (cat. no. 42603). Laccase from Pleurotus sajor-caju was purified through two chromatographic steps (details in [21,22]). Spectrophotometric analyses were carried out with UltroSpec 2100 pro (Amersham Bioscience). Concentrations of substrates and products were also checked by UV–HPLC and GC–MS, using previously described methods [23,24]. 2.1 Synthesis of IPS/MnTDCPP IPS/MnTDCPP was synthesized as previously described [17], with minor modifications. Briefly, 10g plain silica gel was functionalized by overnight reaction at 80°C with 10mmol 3-(1-imidazolyl)propylcarbamoyl-3′-aminopropyl-triethoxysilane (synthetized as described in [17], Fig. 1a) in 10mL diglyme. The activated silica (IPS) was washed consecutively with 0.5M HCl, H2O, 0.1M NaOH and H2O again. The wet silica was then carefully dried overnight in a vacuum oven. IPS (1g) was then treated with 20mg MnTDCPP, solubilized in 10mL of DMSO, then the reaction mixture was kept at 25°C in the dark under stirring overnight. After this, excess metalloporphine was washed away with DMSO and 2-propanol. The bound MnTDCPP was quantified by the difference in absorption at 462nm (the λ max of the MnTDCPP Soret band), as described in [17]. 2.2 Synthesis of PSG/MnTDCPP Pyridyl functionalization of plain silica was accomplished using 4-pyridyl-methyl-carbamoyl-3-aminopropyl-triethoxysilane (Fig. 1b). This was synthetized by reaction between 10mmol of (3-isocyanatopropyl)triethoxysilane and 10mmol of 4-(aminomethyl)pyridine (4-picolylamine) in 10mL diglyme (18h, 25°C). This organosilane was used to functionalize plain silica using the same procedure described above (compare Section 2.1), to obtain pyridyl-functionalized silica gel (PSG). PSG was then treated with MnTDCPP, as described in Section 2.1. 2.3 Characterization of the supports FT-IR spectra (resolution 4cm−1) were recorded after the samples were obtained as KBr pellets, with a KBr beam-splitter and KBr windows on a Thermo Nicolet 5700 spectrometer at room temperature. Functionalization degree was determined through total nitrogen analysis. Briefly, oxidant solution was prepared by dissolving 46.5gL−1 potassium peroxydisulfate, 15gL−1 boric acid, and 7gL−1 sodium hydroxide in bidistilled water. Proper amounts of the samples were suspended in 2.5mL H2O and 0.7mL oxidant solution, and treated for 30′ at 120°C. Then, supernatant was acidified with 15μL H2SO4 98%, and absorbance at 220nm was recorded [25]. Alternatively, nitrate was determined through modified Griess method [26]. Glycine was used as the standard for calibration curve. 2.4 Catalytic activity measurements Routine measurements of catalytic activity were performed through photometric assays. A mixture containing 10mg of catalyst suspended in 2mL of 200mM buffer solution containing 2mM VA and 8.8mM hydrogen peroxide, was kept stirring at 25°C in the dark. Increase in absorbance at 310nm was measured after 30′ incubation, to detect the formed veratraldehyde (ɛ 310 =9300M−1 cm−1). ARS bleaching was quantified at 25°C by spectrophotometric assay: 10mg of catalyst were added, in a final volume of 2mL, to 200mM buffer, 8.8mM H2O2 and 0.5mM ARS. The mixtures were kept stirring in the dark at 25°C for 30′, then pH was corrected to 7 with 0.2mL of McIlvaine buffer 1M (pH 7) and the absorbance decrease at 520nm was recorded (ɛ 520 =7200M−1cm−1). Alternatively, the dye azure B was used as the substrate. To a mixture containing 200mM buffer, 0.88mM hydrogen peroxide, and 0.01mM azure B, in a final volume of 2mL, 10mg of catalyst were added. After 30′ of stirring in the dark, decrease in absorbance at 651nm was detected (ɛ 651 =48,800M−1 cm−1). For certain experiments, the well-known hydroxyl radical scavenger 0.1M mannitol was also added. The actual hydrogen peroxide concentration was determined by KMnO4 titration. In a series of experiments, hydrogen peroxide was replaced by Luperox® (t-butyl hydroperoxide) as the oxidant, using the same final concentration. The ability of the heterogenous catalysts to bleach textile dyes was studied using 10mg of catalyst in 2mL of 200mM buffer solution containing 8.8mM hydrogen peroxide and a proper concentration of the selected dye. The routine analyses were performed using the following concentrations of dyes: 0.5mM ARS, 0.31mM PNS, 2mM XO, 0.15mM MB, 1.5mM MG, and 1.25mM MO, according to previously reported protocols [19]. Reaction was monitored photometrically using the λ max and molar extinction coefficients reported in [19]. In order to test catalytic performance at various pH values, some McIlvaine buffers were used: pH 3, pH 4, pH 5, pH 6, pH 7, and pH 8. All experiments were performed both in the absence and in the presence of 50mM malonic acid and 1mM MnSO4 to assay MnP-like activity. Multi-cyclic runs were performed by regenerating catalysts between consecutive cycles with repeated washings with water and 2-propanol, until no residue of products/substrates was photometrically detected. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of the adducts IPS/MnTDCPP and PSG/MnTDCPP Imidazole from histidine side chain is the natural ligand of porphyrins in ligninolytic peroxidases (lignin, manganese, and versatile peroxidases), being therefore the ligand of choice for biomimetic immobilization of synthetic metalloporphines. However, also pyridine is able to effectively coordinate metalloporphines and positively modulate their catalytic activity [18,20], mainly because of its higher electron-withdrawing character. Accordingly, the first aim of the present study has been the preparation of two silica-based supports grafted respectively with imidazole (IPS) and pyridine (PSG). This goal was accomplished by the well-known reaction between primary aliphatic primary amines and alkyl isocyanates. Two organosilanes were synthesized according to the reactions (a) and (b) in Fig. 1, using (3-isocyanatopropyl)triethoxysilane and N-(3-aminopropyl)imidazole or 4-(aminomethyl)pyridine. These N,N′-disubstituted urea-organosilanes were then directly used to functionalize plain silica gel, yielding imidazolyl-grafted silica (IPS) and pyridyl-grafted silica (PSG), respectively. Functionalization degree was estimated by total nitrogen determination (Table 1 ). Imidazolyl-silane was approximately 4-fold more reactive than pyridyl-counterpart (about 200 vs 50μmol of ligand per gram of silica). However, both values were adequate, being significantly higher than maximum metalloporphine loading possible. In fact, about 15 and 18μmol of MnTDCPP were immobilized respectively per gram of IPS and PSG. It was not possible to immobilize higher amounts of MnTDCPP, probably due to steric hindrance, affecting both effectiveness of the coordination bond and catalytic efficiency of immobilized metalloporphine. Similar phenomena have been already observed in similar cases of immobilization [17,18]. FT-IR analysis confirmed the functionalization of silica gel (Fig. 2 ). Significant spectral modifications were induced by silanization. In particular, bathochromic shift of about 20cm−1 of main OH band is present both in IPS and PSG. Besides, silanization resulted in the appearance of additional bands at 1645 and 1571cm−1, possibly deriving from NH bending and/or heteroaromatic rings. A band at 663cm−1 was also visible, possibly belonging to SiC bond. 3.2 Catalytic activity of the adducts IPS/MnTDCPP and PSG/MnTDCPP The main goal of this study was the full comparison of imidazole and pyridine as ligands for biomimetic-immobilized metalloporphyrins. As a consequence, a number of substrates were included, to better compare the effect of the two ligands on the catalytic activity. Veratryl alcohol (3,4-dimethoxybenzyl alcohol, VA) is the most common LiP substrate [27], due to an easy photometric assay involving the formation of veratraldehyde (λ max =310nm). Moreover, its aromatic non-phenolic character avoids interference by low-redox potential peroxidase-like and laccase-like activity, and properly discerns catalytic activities able to oxidize lignin or lignin-like substances. The dye azure B (N,N,N′-trimethylthionin, AzB) has been suggested as substrate for LiP [28], being therefore included in this study. In our previous reports [12,16], we also suggested alizarin red S (1,2-dihydroxy-9,10-anthraquinonesulfonic acid sodium salt, ARS) as a suitable colored substrate for biomimetic metalloporphyrins. In fact, ARS can be only partially oxidized by one-electron transfer mechanisms. Contrarily, oxygen transfer route allows its complete oxidation [12]. Therefore, ARS allowed discriminating between these two catalytic routes. Hydrogen peroxide is the physiological oxidant used by LiP and MnP, but also Luperox® (tert-butyl hydroperoxide) was used for comparison. Luperox® is slightly less reactive than hydrogen peroxide, but when catalysis follows a homolytic mechanism, it does not produce the very destructive (for the metalloporphine) hydroxyl radical, but instead the less reactive t-butoxyl radical [29]. As a primary goal, the effects of pH and Mn(II) as redox mediator have been investigated. The results for VA, ARS and AzB are reported in Fig. 3 , using hydrogen peroxide as the oxidant. Whereas negligible activity was detected below pH 7, a general optimum at pH 8 resulted for all tested substrates. Mn(II) did not affect catalytic activity, ruling out the possibility of MnP-like activity for VA and AzB. Only in the case of ARS a slight increase in conversion rate was detected in the presence of this redox mediator at pH 7 (about +50% for PSG/MnTDCPP) and 8 (about +25% for PSG/MnTDCPP). PSG/MnTDCPP was significantly more active than IPS/MnTDCPP, as confirmed by the conversion rates in 1h, at pH 8, reported in Table 2 . Pyridine as the ligand led to a 2-fold higher conversion of VA and ARS, and 3-fold higher conversion of AzB. These data were confirmed by k cat values: for instance, IPS/MnTDCPP presented a turnover frequency of 0.13min−1, using VA as the substrate. Under the same conditions, PSG/MnTDCPP had a k cat of 0.23min−1. The products profile greatly differed between the two catalysts. In fact, PSG/MnTDCPP led to about 57% selectivity in veratraldehyde and 11% in veratric acid. In the case of IPS/MnTDCPP only 12% of veratraldehyde was detected. In both cases no other products were detectable using both HPLC/UV and GC/MS, including 2-hydroxymethyl-5-methoxy-1,4-benzoquinone [18]. This is in accordance with the results obtained with similar catalytic adducts [17], when the main part of the products escaped both HPLC and GC analysis, since the oxidation possibly went beyond one-electron oxidation (and corresponding veratraldehyde formation), and yielded more polar products such as dicarboxylic acids, or oligomerized/polymerized products. In Fig. 4 the effects of pH and Mn(II) are reported in the presence of Luperox® as the oxidant. A similar pattern as above can be pointed out, since pH 8 was the optimum for all reducing substrates and Mn(II) did not positively affected the catalysis (the only exception was at pH 7 using ARS as the substrate, when an approximate +30% activity was detected for both IPS/MnTDCPP and PSG/MnTDCPP). The comparison in Table 2, however, shows that Luperox® was slightly less reactive in all cases in comparison with hydrogen peroxide. Accordingly, hydrogen peroxide should be preferred as the oxidant also for large-scale applications. In fact, one should also consider that hydrogen peroxide is available at a relatively low price, is completely miscible with water (no organic solvents needed), and releases only environmentally harmless products (water and molecular oxygen) during degradation. In both cases the homolytic cleavage of Compound zero analog was ruled out, as mannitol (a well-known OH quencher) was not able to affect catalytic activity (not shown). A significant difference between IPS/MnTDCPP and PSG/MnTDCPP was observed in the oxidation of AzB. In fact, during their catalysis, spectral changes in UV and visible regions are completely different (Fig. 5 ). This could be probably associated with a different molecular mechanism. Similar differences can be observed during the catalysis of two ligninolytic enzymes like laccase and LiP, both able to oxidize phenothiazine dyes [28,30], such as AzB. The comparison with the spectral modification occurring during enzymic catalysis (not shown) suggests a similar molecular pathway for laccase and IPS/MnTDCPP. Whereas LiP leads to the same spectral pattern of PSG/MnTDCPP. Immobilized metalloporphines were also investigated about their ability to oxidize several textile dyes, belonging to different chemical classes (anthraquinones, phenylphenazinium, triarylmethanes, phenothiazines, azo-dyes). The results are reported in Fig. 6 . All dyes were efficiently bleached, suggesting a broad substrate range for both catalysts. Even in this case Mn(II) did not significantly affect catalytic activity. Whereas PSG/MnTDCPP confirmed its higher catalytic performances. After the catalysis, both IPS/MnTDCPP and PSG/MnTDCPP can be recovered, exhaustively washed, and re-used for several catalytic cycles. Table 3 summarizes the results obtained for multi-cycle re-use of the catalysts using VA, ARS, and AzB. In all cases, up to 10 cycles at least 30% of starting catalytic activity was maintained. This is a crucial feature from applicative perspective. IPS/MnTDCPP was able in all cases to preserve a higher catalytic activity than PSG/MnTDCPP, suggesting that imidazole more efficiently protects metalloporphine from degradation (possibly due in large extent to the oxidant itself). The drop in catalytic activity between different cycles could be partially due to oxidative degradation of the metalloporphine, and in part to tight adsorption of substrates and arising products on the silica supports. So, besides different surface properties between IPS/MnTDCPP and PSG/MnTDCPP (possibly leading to differential substrates/products adsorption), these evidences could be explained taking into account the higher electron-withdrawing effect of pyridine, if compared to imidazole. This effect may enhance redox potential of immobilized metalloporphine, making more reactive (namely, more electrophilic) the Compound I analog. However, this higher reactivity (confirmed by the whole results described above) may also render the porphine macrocycle more sensitive to nucleophilic attack, leading to faster catalyst degradation and deactivation. Accordingly, it is not surprising that MnTDCPP is more protected against oxidative degradation when imidazole is the ligand. Under all the tested conditions, no measurable elution of MnTDCPP and/or manganese ion was detected. 3.3 Molecular mechanism insights The resemblance of spectral changes observed along laccase action on AzB and that of IPS/MnTDCP on the same substrate strongly speaks in favor of a one-electron oxidation mechanism promoted by the bioinspired catalyst, quite resembling that well known for laccases and “classical” peroxidases such as horseradish peroxidase. In fact, laccases – that belong to the so-called Blue Multi-Copper Oxidases (BMCO) – usually contain a tetracupric cluster [31], where a type I cupric ion is devoted to abstract one electron from a suitable electron-rich substrate (usually polyphenols or also aromatic amines, aminophenols, or so on). On the whole, the type I copper cycles between the cupric and cuprous states, whereas dioxygen is specifically bound within a tricopper cluster (one type II and two coupled type III ions [32]) and gradually reduced to water [33]. In other words, any laccase-mediated interaction between the reducing substrates and dioxygen is avoided, and the product(s) formation is driven essentially by the nature and reactivity of the particular radical arising from the substrate itself. Obviously, a direct reaction between the substrate radical and excess dioxygen could well take place, but the enzyme does not directly influence its occurrence. Completely different is the case of hemoperoxidases, that compulsorily form a Compound I as the key intermediate in substrate oxidation/oxygenation: this is a high-valent ferryl Fe(IV) O derivative of heme, also showing a radical character, hosted by the porphyrin macrocycle [15]. The Compound I is a very strong oxidizing agent, and its ability in transferring its oxygen atom to reducing substrates such as sulfides, alkenes, and in general to activated CH bonds has been firmly established [34,35]. For “classical” peroxidases, the oxygen transfer is a nearly negligible reaction in comparison with the “usual” one-electron transfer; however, the things look very different in the case of high potential peroxidases (such as LiP and MnP), peroxygenases, and P-450 enzymes [36], where oxygen transfer is important and in certain cases the only observed mode of action. Such a transfer in most cases takes place through an “oxygen rebound” mechanism where the Compound I extracts one electron from the substrate; the arising radical does not abandon the active site of the enzyme, and quickly reacts with the formed Compound II [15,37]. The oxygen transfer then follows, thus restoring the enzyme resting state and releasing the oxygenated substrate. Such a mechanism could be suggested when LiP acts on AzB as shown by our experiments, the spectral pattern observed during LiP action on AzB is sharply different from that observed in the presence of laccase. Owing to the obligate mode of action of laccase, based on one-electron abstraction from the substrate, the different pattern observed with LiP can be explained only by a quite different mechanism, and an oxygenation going through the oxygen rebound mechanism seems quite reasonable and most probable. The particular 3D structure of LiP explains its higher redox potential in comparison with horseradish peroxidase. In the case of the PSG/MnTDCP, the peculiar features of the pyridyl moiety must be kept into the due account, contrarily to imidazole, pyridine is a typical electron-poor heterocycle, anyway capable of donating its electron couple on the nitrogen atom to the metal ion at the center of the porphine macrocycle. In this way, a typical sigma complex is formed. However, pyridine (much more easily than imidazole) could accept d electron density from the metal ion into its anti-bonding π* orbitals. This stabilizes the resting state of the metalloporphine complex, in comparison to the high-valent states Compounds I and II, which explains the stronger oxidizing power of PSG/MnTDCP in comparison with IPS/MnTDCP (in accordance to recent evidence observed in homogenous phase [20]), and the different mode of action, favoring oxygen transfer in detriment of the simple one-electron transfer. However, such a stronger oxidizing power is the responsible of the more rapid self-destruction of the pyridyl-bound metalloporphine along the multi-cycle experiments. The same considerations could explain the different behavior of the two catalysts toward VA oxidation. In fact, the imidazole-based system in this case produces only a little amount of veratraldehyde, together with a mixture of unknown products. One could hypothesize that the arising Compound II is not reactive enough to promote further electron abstraction giving (through hydration and deprotonation) to veratraldehyde. Instead, oligomers and/or other degradation species derived from the one-electron abstraction form VA could reasonably be the favored products. In the case of the pyridine-based catalyst, the stronger oxidizing power of both Compounds I and II presumably lead to a “regular” oxidation of VA to the aldehyde, with a reaction pathway paralleling that well known for LiP [38]. Somewhat surprisingly, under the chosen experimental conditions, no significant amounts of the well-known byproduct, 2-hydroxymethyl-5-methoxy-1,4-benzoquinone, was found at the end of the oxidation experiments, regardless to the particular catalyst was used. As a point of fact, no turbidity nor discoloration of the supernatant was observed (different from imidazole-based catalyst), thus suggesting that a fraction of the original substrate was further oxidized to veratric acid and – possibly through a “direct” oxygen transfer – to muconic derivatives and/or very polar degradation products (as observed for other metalloporphines-based systems [39,40]), escaping both HPLC and GC–MS analyses. Similarly undetectable could be polymerization products arising from quinones via radical coupling (in this case tight adsorption onto silica of these products could not be ruled out). 4 Conclusions Both imidazole- and pyridine-functionalized silica-based supports have proved able to effectively heterogenize MnTDCPP, mimicking the active site of ligninolytic peroxidases. However, significant catalytic differences turned out, since pyridyl-immobilized metalloporphine (PSG/MnTDCPP) led to higher conversion rates. Such results give precious insights about the role of the ligand in biomimetic immobilization of metalloporphines. Not surprisingly, the electron deficiency of pyridine resulted in a higher catalytic activity of PSG/MnTDCPP (possibly due to Compound I analog higher redox potential). Unfortunately, this higher reactivity also turned out in higher instability of PSG/MnTDCPP, suggesting imidazole as the ligand of choice for more stable catalysts. Very different products pattern and mechanisms of catalysis also emerged. The specific electronic features of pyridine were suggested to explain also the proposed different mode of action, possibly favoring oxygen transfer instead of one-electron transfer. These outcomes should allow to more rationally design the supports for immobilization of metalloporphines, depending on the specific aims of the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: This paper describes the immobilization of 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(2,6-dichlorophenyl)porphine-manganese(III) through coordinative bond onto imidazolyl- and pyridyl-grafted silica, emulating the active site of ligninolytic peroxidases. To this purpose, plain silica gel was functionalized with two organosilanes: the first bearing an imidazolyl functionality, the other one bearing a pyridyl functionality. Manganese-porphine was then immobilized onto the two modified silicas. The two catalytic adducts have been fully characterized to point out the effect of the ligands on their catalytic features. Pyridine-immobilized metalloporphine was found to be a much more performant catalyst, giving significantly higher conversion rates with all the tested substrates: a lignin-model compound such as veratryl alcohol, the lignin peroxidase well-known substrate azure B, and recalcitrant textile dyes such as alizarin red S, phenosafranine, methylene blue, methyl green, xylenol orange, and methyl orange. Imidazole-immobilized metalloporphine on the contrary has proved to be more stable than its pyridine-based counterpart. Besides, the ligands seem to promote different catalytic pathways in the two adducts. These results allow giving rational and rigorous insights about the effect of the ligands during the immobilization of metalloporphines, thus helping in the design of catalysts with specific feature (i.e. stability, reactivity).
coredata.dc:title: Imidazole versus pyridine as ligands for metalloporphine immobilization in ligninolytic peroxidases-like biomimetic catalysts

coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
